messageBody:
Well, first of all, it should have read "without resorting to soak
testing". Sorry.

Soak testing is where you run tests in a random loop on a fixture that is
not being reset between tests in order to see if there are order
dependencies, timing problems, state issues or if the fixture is being
left in an invalid condition by one or more tests. Soak tests will
identify failures that often won't be found any other way, but they are
notorious for identifying failures that cannot be diagnosed or fixed
because the fixture may get into a bad state in one iteration and not
actually fail until many iterations later. This is especially a problem in
testing C/C++ code.

Doing invariant checking on each state change means that you
(theoretically) know about the invalid state immediately rather than
finding out about it after some complex sequence of events causes the
failure to manifest. This makes it much easier to find and fix.

On Mon, 17 Dec 2001, Holliday, Donald B. (LNG-SHEP) wrote:

> <snip>get better diagnostics resorting to soak testing</snip>
>
> What is "soak testing"?
>
> Donald Holliday
>
>
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: evought@... [mailto:evought@...]
> Sent: Monday, December 17, 2001 9:06 AM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: Re: [junit] Invariants: method within class or within test
> class?
>
>
> I find that option #1 is superior. As you say, it reduces exposure to
> internals. It also gives one the option of invoking that code in the
> field. Especially where there are user accessable APIs, I find it handy to
> ask a user to invoke invariants checking around problem code while
> diagnosing a possible API bug. If your assertInvariants(..) method is
> recursive, it is also not difficult to add a menu option that will invoke
> a full internal state check at run-time.
>
> I always have the invariants checks run in my unit tests. This gives you
> the ability to catch a lot more bugs and get better diagnostics resorting
> to soak testing. A lot of times, your unit test may pass but leave the
> class-under-test in a bad state. In a real program, the next statement
> would fail, but its never caught in your test because the fixture is
> recycled. Invoking the invariants tests after state changes in tests is
> cheap and saves headaches in the long run.
>
> On Fri, 14 Dec 2001, Robertson, Don wrote:
>
> > Let's assume that invoking an assertInvariants() method within your
> class's
> > methods is too expensive to be practical, but you want it for the purpose
> of
> > unit testing anyway. Would it be structurally superior to :
> >
> > 1) Implement such a method within the actual class and invoke it from the
> > test case. The main benefits I see are minimal exposure of the class's
> > internals (although it *is* white box testing after all), and visual
> > proximity of the invariant conditions for implementors/modifiers. The
> > negative is that there is "dead code" (from a runtime perspective) within
> > the class.
> > 2) Allow access to internal state within the class and write the
> > assertInvariants() method within the test class(es). The benefits are
> visual
> > proximity of the invariant conditions with the other functional
> description
> > of the class, and no dead code in the runtime class. The negative is the
> > need for exposure of more internal state.
> >
> > Opinions?
> >
> >
> > A second "meta" question might be whether you think it is worthwhile to
> > check invariant conditions within your unit tests as a default behavior,
> or
> > is it overkill?
> >
> > Don
> >
> >
> >
> >
